title: Réjean Lemelin
text:
Réjean M. "Reggie" Lemelin (born November 19, 1954) is a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> former professional <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a> <a href="goaltender">goaltender</a> and coach. Lemelin played in the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a> (NHL) for the <a href="Atlanta%20Flames">Atlanta Flames</a>, <a href="Calgary%20Flames">Calgary Flames</a> and <a href="Boston%20Bruins">Boston Bruins</a>. After his playing career, Lemelin spent 13 years as a goaltending coach for the <a href="Philadelphia%20Flyers">Philadelphia Flyers</a>, who had originally drafted him into the NHL.
Playing career.
As a youth, Lemelin played in the 1965, 1966 and 1967 <a href="Quebec%20International%20Pee-Wee%20Hockey%20Tournament">Quebec International Pee-Wee Hockey Tournament</a>s with a <a href="minor%20ice%20hockey">minor ice hockey</a> team from <a href="Charlesbourg%2C%20Quebec%20City">Orsainville, Quebec City</a>.
After playing two seasons in the <a href="Quebec%20Major%20Junior%20Hockey%20League">QMJHL</a> with the <a href="Sherbrooke%20Beavers">Sherbrooke Beavers</a>, Lemelin joined the <a href="North%20American%20Hockey%20League">North American Hockey League</a>'s <a href="Philadelphia%20Firebirds%20%28hockey%29">Philadelphia Firebirds</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="Philadelphia%20Flyers">Philadelphia Flyers</a> in the seventh round, 125th overall, in the <a href="1974%20NHL%20amateur%20draft">1974 NHL amateur draft</a>, and was also selected by the <a href="Chicago%20Cougars">Chicago Cougars</a> in the <a href="1974%20WHA%20Amateur%20Draft">1974 WHA Amateur Draft</a>; however, he never played in the WHA, due to an argument with management. His NHL debut came with the <a href="Atlanta%20Flames">Atlanta Flames</a> during the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20NHL%20season">1978–79 season</a>.
Lemelin remained with the Flames through their move to <a href="Calgary%20Flames">Calgary</a>, where he enjoyed the most success of his career. He split goaltending duties with <a href="Pat%20Riggin">Pat Riggin</a> and then <a href="Don%20Edwards%20%28ice%20hockey%29">Don Edwards</a>, earning the starting job in <a href="1982%E2%80%9383%20NHL%20season">1983</a>, In 1984, he was named to the <a href="Canadian%20national%20men%27s%20ice%20hockey%20team">Canadian team</a> that played in the <a href="1984%20Canada%20Cup">1984 Canada Cup</a>. He played in two games, earning a win and a loss. After losing his starting job in Calgary to <a href="Mike%20Vernon%20%28ice%20hockey%29">Mike Vernon</a>, he joined the <a href="Boston%20Bruins">Boston Bruins</a> for the <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20NHL%20season">1987–88 season</a>, and teamed with <a href="Andy%20Moog">Andy Moog</a> to win the NHL's <a href="William%20M.%20Jennings%20Trophy">William M. Jennings Trophy</a> (for fewest team goals allowed) in the <a href="1989%E2%80%9390%20NHL%20season">1989–90 season</a>.
After battling numerous injuries Lemelin retired during the <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20NHL%20season">1992–93 season</a> with his final game on December 29, 1992 in Winnipeg against the <a href="Winnipeg%20Jets%20%281972%E2%80%931996%29">Jets</a>. In his NHL career, he appeared in 507 games and had only two losing seasons.
After 13 seasons as the goaltending coach for the <a href="Philadelphia%20Flyers">Philadelphia Flyers</a>, he was replaced on June 25, 2009, by <a href="Jeff%20Reese">Jeff Reese</a>. As of 2010, he was active in Boston area charity hockey games, playing as a goaltender with the Boston Bruins Alumni exhibition team.
Personal life.
Lemelin married his wife, Rona, in July 1976. They have two children together, Brian and <a href="Stephanie%20Lemelin">Stephanie</a>.
